Course Outline

  1. Analysis of 3-D state of stress and strain in materials, Equilibrium equations, relationships between strain and displacement, strain compatibility
  2. 3-D stress-strain relationship for elastic solids (Hooke’s law). The limitations of elastic response, yielding of metals.The general considerations of #1, #2 will be applied to a number of different types of stress analysis problems that arise in practical applications. These include:
  3. St. Venant torsion of bars with non-circular cross-sections, including thin-walled sections
  4. 2-D Problems of plane stress and plane strain in polar coordinates: thick-walled cylinder under pressure (pipes, pressure vessels), composite pipes and shrink-fit problems
  5. Bending of thin flat plates (building construction, auto body panels,etc.)Suggested Reading:Full course notes will be posted to LEARN in the beginning of the term.

Resources: Course Notes, Advanced Strength of Materials (J.P. Den Hartog, 1952), Elasticity (P.C. Chou and N. J. Pagano, 1967), Advanced Mechanics of Materials (Roman Solecki and Jay Conant), Review

3D Stress System

Derivation of Stress Matrix

The stress at a single point, say Q, is found using x, y, and z components. These components are all made up of 3 components themselves, for a total of 9 components. See below:

σ(x)=σxi⃗+τxyj⃗+τxzk⃗\sigma^{(x)}=\sigma_x\vec{i}+\tau_{xy}\vec{j}+\tau_{xz}\vec{k} σ(x)=σx​i+τxy​j​+τxz​k

σ(y)=τyxi⃗+σyj⃗+τyzk⃗\sigma^{(y)}=\tau_{yx}\vec{i}+\sigma_y\vec{j}+\tau_{yz}\vec{k} σ(y)=τyx​i+σy​j​+τyz​k

σ(z)=τzxi⃗+τzyj⃗+σzk⃗\sigma^{(z)}=\tau_{zx}\vec{i}+\tau_{zy}\vec{j}+\sigma_{z}\vec{k} σ(z)=τzx​i+τzy​j​+σz​k

i,j, and k are components of the normal vector, N, that the stress σN\sigma_NσN​ goes through. Values of stress are inputted into the symmetric stress matrix

3D has applications for beams, torsion of bars, bending of plates, analysis of shells, and plane stress.

In 3D stress systems, sides exert the same distribution of force as applied onto it to maintain equilibrium. This resultant force is F divided by arbitrary area ΔA\Delta{A}ΔA. F has i, j, and k components F=Fxi+Fyj+FzkF=F_xi+F_yj+F_zkF=Fx​i+Fy​j+Fz​k. Since these components are projections onto planes, individual forces cab be found with dot product i⋅Fi\cdot{F}i⋅F, alternatively ∣i∣∣F∣cos⁡∢(i,F)=∣F∣cos⁡∢(i,F)|i||F|\cos\sphericalangle{(i,F)}=|F|\cos\sphericalangle{(i,F)}∣i∣∣F∣cos∢(i,F)=∣F∣cos∢(i,F). It is also noted that F is a vector sum of normal force and shear force F⃗=FN⃗+FV⃗\vec{F}=\vec{F_N}+\vec{F_V}F=FN​​+FV​​.

At a single point, σ=lim⁡ΔA→0FΔA\sigma=\lim_{\Delta{A}\to{0}}\frac{F}{\Delta{A}}σ=limΔA→0​ΔAF​. The normal stress and shear stress components apply this formula and are added together to form the stress vector.

Further, cubes of dimension Δx\Delta_xΔx​, Δy\Delta_yΔy​ & Δz\Delta_zΔz​ have stress vectors along their planes. These can be in the positive [x,y,z] direction [σx,σy,σz][\sigma_x, \sigma_y, \sigma_z][σx​,σy​,σz​] or negative [x,y,z] direction [σx′,σy′,σz′][\sigma_x\prime,\sigma_y\prime,\sigma_z\prime ][σx​′,σy​′,σz​′]. These are each made up of components along each axis. For example, σxy\sigma_{xy}σxy​ is stress in x vector along y axis. Total vector σx=σxxi+σxyj+σxzk\sigma_x=\sigma_{xx}i+\sigma_{xy}j+\sigma_{xz}kσx​=σxx​i+σxy​j+σxz​k.

To consider the entire element, a body force β\betaβ is also considered as the force per unit volume. For gravity, β=−ρgk\beta=-\rho{gk}β=−ρgk. For equilibrium, the below expression is used:

[σx+σx′]ΔyΔz+[σy+σy′]ΔxΔz+[σz+σz′]ΔxΔy+βΔxΔyΔz(3D Equilibrium)[\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{x}\prime]\Delta_y\Delta_z+[\sigma_{y}+\sigma_{y}\prime]\Delta_x\Delta_z+[\sigma_{z}+\sigma_{z}\prime]\Delta_x\Delta_y+\beta\Delta_x\Delta_y\Delta_z\tag{3D Equilibrium} [σx​+σx​′]Δy​Δz​+[σy​+σy​′]Δx​Δz​+[σz​+σz​′]Δx​Δy​+βΔx​Δy​Δz​(3D Equilibrium)

From here, you can see that axial dimensions approaching zero lead to the axial stress being equal to the negative of their prime counterparts. This demonstrates equal and opposite forces.

The tetrahedron can be used to show this relationship with an inclined plane, with ΔAx\Delta{A_x}ΔAx​ is the area on y-z plane, ΔA\Delta{A}ΔA is area on oblique plane, σN\sigma_NσN​ is stress on oblique plane with unit normal N, and σx′\sigma_x\primeσx​′ is stress on yz plane. The stress vector acting on any plane through a point can be obtained if we know the plane's orientation (Nx,Ny,Nx)(N_x,N_y,N_x)(Nx​,Ny​,Nx​), which may be referred to as [l,m,n], and the stress vectors σx,σy,σz\sigma_x, \sigma_y, \sigma_zσx​,σy​,σz​ at the point with the below:

σN=σxNx+σyNy+σzNz\sigma_N=\sigma_xN_x+\sigma_yN_y+\sigma_zN_z σN​=σx​Nx​+σy​Ny​+σz​Nz​

[σxxlσyxmσzxnσNxσxylσyymσzynσNyσxzlσyzmσzznσNx]\left[\begin{array}{c c c|c} \sigma_{xx}l & \sigma_{yx}m & \sigma_{zx}n & \sigma_{N_x} \\ \sigma_{xy}l & \sigma_{yy}m & \sigma_{zy}n & \sigma_{N_y} \\ \sigma_{xz}l & \sigma_{yz}m & \sigma_{zz}n & \sigma_{N_x}\\ \end{array}\right]⎣⎡​σxx​lσxy​lσxz​l​σyx​mσyy​mσyz​m​σzx​nσzy​nσzz​n​σNx​​σNy​​σNx​​​⎦⎤​

(σ)=(σxxσxyσxzσyxσyyσyzσzxσzyσzz)(\sigma)= \begin{pmatrix} \sigma_{xx} & \sigma_{xy} & \sigma_{xz} \\ \sigma_{yx} & \sigma_{yy} & \sigma_{yz} \\ \sigma_{zx} & \sigma_{zy} & \sigma_{zz} \\ \end{pmatrix}(σ)=⎝⎛​σxx​σyx​σzx​​σxy​σyy​σzy​​σxz​σyz​σzz​​⎠⎞​

The stress matrix is always symmetric for homogeneous, linear elastic, and isotropic conditions

Derivation of Transformation of Axes

With the rotation of axes, [I,J,K] replace [i,j,k]. I=Ixi+Iyj+IzkI=I_xi+I_yj+I_zkI=Ix​i+Iy​j+Iz​k and Ix2+Iy2+Iz2=1I_x^2+I_y^2+I_z^2=1Ix2​+Iy2​+Iz2​=1.

Ix=i⋅I=cos⁡∢(i,I)I_x=i\cdot{I}=\cos{\sphericalangle{(i,I)}} Ix​=i⋅I=cos∢(i,I)

Jx=cos⁡∢(i,J)J_x=\cos\sphericalangle{(i,J)} Jx​=cos∢(i,J)

Kx=cos⁡∢(i,K)K_x=\cos\sphericalangle{(i,K)} Kx​=cos∢(i,K)

σX=σXXI+σXYJ+σXZK(Stress on Y-Z Plane)\sigma_X=\sigma_{XX}I+\sigma_{XY}J+\sigma_{XZ}K\tag{Stress on Y-Z Plane} σX​=σXX​I+σXY​J+σXZ​K(Stress on Y-Z Plane)

σX=σxIx+σyIy+σzIz\sigma_X=\sigma_xI_x+\sigma_yI_y+\sigma_zI_z σX​=σx​Ix​+σy​Iy​+σz​Iz​

σx=σxxi+σxyj+σxzk\sigma_x=\sigma_{xx}i+\sigma_{xy}j+\sigma_{xz}k σx​=σxx​i+σxy​j+σxz​k

Knowing that σXX\sigma_{XX}σXX​ is I⋅σXI\cdot{\sigma_X}I⋅σX​, σXY\sigma_{XY}σXY​ is J⋅σXJ\cdot{\sigma_X}J⋅σX​ and using the formulas above, formulas can be found for the transformation of axes

In the case of stress only on the X-Y plane, I=cos⁡θi+sin⁡θjI=\cos\theta{i}+\sin\theta{j}I=cosθi+sinθj and J=−sin⁡θi+cos⁡θjJ=-\sin\theta{i}+\cos\theta{j}J=−sinθi+cosθj

Principal Stresses

Simplifications are typically made in 2D case. For example, beams assumed to only have bending stress as non-zero. A 3D understanding is req'd to understand the simplifications/

For any 3D state of stress, there are 3 mutually perpendicular planes, on which the shearing stress are zero. The normal stresses to these planes are principle stresses, and normals to the planes are principle directions. Principal stresses are important bc they introduce the failure criteria, such as Tresca and Von Mises. These form a stress tensor.

Since shear is zero, (σNx−σl)i⃗+(σNy−σm)j⃗+(σNz−σn)k⃗=0(\sigma_{N_x}-\sigma{l})\vec{i}+(\sigma_{N_y}-\sigma{m})\vec{j}+(\sigma_{N_z}-\sigma{n})\vec{k}=0(σNx​​−σl)i+(σNy​​−σm)j​+(σNz​​−σn)k=0. Therefore, the below are found:

σxxl+σxym+σxzn−σl=0\sigma_{xx}l+\sigma_{xy}m+\sigma_{xz}n-\sigma{l}=0 σxx​l+σxy​m+σxz​n−σl=0

σxyl+σyym+σyzn−σm=0\sigma_{xy}l+\sigma_{yy}m+\sigma_{yz}n-\sigma{m}=0 σxy​l+σyy​m+σyz​n−σm=0

σxzl+σyzm+σzzn−σn=0\sigma_{xz}l+\sigma_{yz}m+\sigma_{zz}n-\sigma{n}=0 σxz​l+σyz​m+σzz​n−σn=0

[σxx−σσxyσxzσxyσyy−σσyzσxzσyzσzz−σ][lmn]=[000] \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{xx}-\sigma & \sigma_{xy} & \sigma_{xz}\\ \sigma_{xy} & \sigma_{yy}-\sigma & \sigma_{yz}\\ \sigma_{xz} & \sigma_{yz} & \sigma_{zz} - \sigma \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} l\\ m\\ n \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0\\0\\0 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​σxx​−σσxy​σxz​​σxy​σyy​−σσyz​​σxz​σyz​σzz​−σ​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​lmn​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​000​⎦⎤​

The matrix is homogeneous because RHS=0, and trivial solution impossible because l2+m2+n2=1l^2+m^2+n^2=1l2+m2+n2=1. Thus, the σ\sigmaσ values can be determined by taking the determinate of the stress matrix equal to zero.

Each distinct eigenvalue has a distinct eigenvector. Thus, if there are only two solutions, only two eigenvectors.

The stress at a point is the same when viewed at a different angles. Rotation of axis can make this clear using the stress invariants.

I1=σxx+σyy+σzzI_1=\sigma_{{xx}}+\sigma_{yy}+\sigma_{zz} I1​=σxx​+σyy​+σzz​

I2=σxσy+σxσz+σyσz−σxy2−σxz2−σyz2I_2 =\sigma_{x}\sigma_y+\sigma_x\sigma_z+\sigma_y\sigma_z-\sigma^2_{xy}-\sigma^2_{xz}-\sigma^2_{yz} I2​=σx​σy​+σx​σz​+σy​σz​−σxy2​−σxz2​−σyz2​

I3=σxσyσz+2σxyσyzσxz−σzσxy2−σyσxz2−σxσyz2I_3=\sigma_x\sigma_y\sigma_z+2\sigma_{xy}\sigma_{yz}\sigma_{xz}-\sigma_{z}\sigma^2_{xy}-\sigma_y\sigma^2_{xz}-\sigma_x\sigma^2_{yz} I3​=σx​σy​σz​+2σxy​σyz​σxz​−σz​σxy2​−σy​σxz2​−σx​σyz2​

To find the eigenvalues, the determinate is taken from the matrix below:

(σ)=[σxx−λσxyσxzσyxσyy−λσyzσzxσzyσzz−λ](\sigma)= \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{xx}-\lambda & \sigma_{xy} & \sigma_{xz} \\ \sigma_{yx} & \sigma_{yy}-\lambda & \sigma_{yz} \\ \sigma_{zx} & \sigma_{zy} & \sigma_{zz}-\lambda \\ \end{bmatrix} (σ)=⎣⎡​σxx​−λσyx​σzx​​σxy​σyy​−λσzy​​σxz​σyz​σzz​−λ​⎦⎤​

Alternatively, use the invariants. These only work if the principal stresses do not equal zero and there are no repeated eigenvalue roots.

σp3−I1σp2+I2σp−I3=0\sigma_p^3-I_1\sigma_p^2+I_2\sigma_p-I_3=0 σp3​−I1​σp2​+I2​σp​−I3​=0

σa=2Scos⁡(α3)+I13(Principal Stress A)\sigma_a=2S\cos{(\frac{\alpha}{3})}+\frac{I_1}{3}\tag{Principal Stress A} σa​=2Scos(3α​)+3I1​​(Principal Stress A)

σb=2Scos⁡(α3+120)+I13(Principal Stress B)\sigma_b=2S\cos{(\frac{\alpha}{3}+120)}+\frac{I_1}{3}\tag{Principal Stress B} σb​=2Scos(3α​+120)+3I1​​(Principal Stress B)

σc=2Scos⁡(α3+240)+I13(Principal Stress C)\sigma_c=2S\cos{(\frac{\alpha}{3}+240)}+\frac{I_1}{3}\tag{Principal Stress C} σc​=2Scos(3α​+240)+3I1​​(Principal Stress C)

Procedure for determining the bases vector (Example):

  1. Compute α\alphaα
    1. R=I123−I2R=\frac{I_1^2}{3}-I_2R=3I12​​−I2​
    2. Q=I1I23−I3−2I1327Q=\frac{I_1I_2}{3}-I_3-\frac{2I_1^3}{27}Q=3I1​I2​​−I3​−272I13​​
    3. T=(R327)0.5T=(\frac{R^3}{27})^{0.5}T=(27R3​)0.5
    4. S=(R3)0.5S=(\frac{R}{3})^{0.5}S=(3R​)0.5
    5. α=arccos⁡(−Q2T)\alpha=\arccos{(\frac{-Q}{2T})}α=arccos(2T−Q​)
  2. Use α\alphaα in principal stress equaations to determine values. Order than from smallest to largest
  3. Solve the determinate of the individual 2x2 components of the 3x3 stress matrix, named aia_iai​, bib_ibi​, and cic_ici​
  4. Normalize these components to lil_ili​, mim_imi​, and nin_ini​, respectively by multiplying by their magnitude Ki=1ai2+bi2+ci2K_i=\frac{1}{\sqrt{a_i^2+b_i^2+c_i^2}}Ki​=ai2​+bi2​+ci2​​1​
  5. V1^=(li,mi,ni)\hat{V_1}=(l_i,m_i,n_i)V1​^​=(li​,mi​,ni​) has been determined! Divide by its magnitude to obtain unit vector e1^\hat{e_1}e1​^​. Repeat Steps 1-4 for the next principal stress
  6. According to the Gram-Schmidt method, the vectors will orthogonalize if the projections from the other vectors are subtracted.
    1. V2′^=V2^−⟨V2^e1^⟩⟨e1^e1^⟩\hat{V_2\prime}=\hat{V_2}-\frac{\langle\hat{V_2}\hat{e_1}\rangle}{\langle\hat{e_1}\hat{e_1}\rangle}V2​′^​=V2​^​−⟨e1​^​e1​^​⟩⟨V2​^​e1​^​⟩​
    2. To find e2^\hat{e_2}e2​^​, divide vector V2′^\hat{V_2\prime}V2​′^​ by its magnitude.
    3. Find vector e3^\hat{e_3}e3​^​ in a similar way except subbing in V3^\hat{V_3}V3​^​ for V2^\hat{V_2}V2​^​, and also subtracting the projection onto e2^\hat{e_2}e2​^​

Maximum and minimum shear stress

To find the angle α\alphaα such that shear or normal stress is maximized, consider the figure below:

Since σN=σxNx+σyNy+σzNz\sigma_N=\sigma_xN_x+\sigma_yN_y+\sigma_zN_zσN​=σx​Nx​+σy​Ny​+σz​Nz​,σN=σ1N1+σ2N2+σ3N3\sigma_N=\sigma_1N_1+\sigma_2N_2+\sigma_3N_3σN​=σ1​N1​+σ2​N2​+σ3​N3​, N1=N⋅N1=sin⁡αN_1=N\cdot{N_1}=\sin\alphaN1​=N⋅N1​=sinα, N2=N⋅N2=cos⁡αN_2=N\cdot{N_2}=\cos\alphaN2​=N⋅N2​=cosα, N3=N⋅N3=0N_3=N\cdot{N_3}=0N3​=N⋅N3​=0, we can say:

N=cos⁡αN1+sin⁡αN2N=\cos\alpha{N_1}+\sin\alpha{N_2} N=cosαN1​+sinαN2​

σN=cos⁡ασ1+sin⁡ασ2\sigma_N=\cos\alpha\sigma_1+\sin\alpha\sigma_2 σN​=cosασ1​+sinασ2​

We also know that σ1=σ1N1\sigma_1=\sigma_1N_1σ1​=σ1​N1​ ec. (principal stress). Therefore. σN=σ1cos⁡αN1+σ2sin⁡N2\sigma_N=\sigma_1\cos\alpha{N_1}+\sigma_2\sin{N_2}σN​=σ1​cosαN1​+σ2​sinN2​. The normal component of this is σ=N⋅σN\sigma=N\cdot{\sigma_N}σ=N⋅σN​. Similarly, the shear component is τ=S⋅σN\tau=S\cdot{\sigma_N}τ=S⋅σN​, where S=−sin⁡αN1+cos⁡αN2S=-\sin\alpha{N_1}+\cos\alpha{N_2}S=−sinαN1​+cosαN2​. See below:

σ=σ1cos⁡2α+σ2sin⁡2α(Normal Stress)\sigma=\sigma_1\cos^2{\alpha}+\sigma_2\sin^2{\alpha}\tag{Normal Stress} σ=σ1​cos2α+σ2​sin2α(Normal Stress)

τ=(σ2−σ1)sin⁡2α2(Shear Stress)\tau=\frac{(\sigma_2-\sigma_1)\sin{2\alpha}}{2}\tag{Shear Stress} τ=2(σ2​−σ1​)sin2α​(Shear Stress)

The maximum shear component is found by taking the derivative with respect to α\alphaα. τ=(σ2−σ1)cos⁡2α\tau=(\sigma_2-\sigma_1)\cos{2\alpha}τ=(σ2​−σ1​)cos2α. At this point, α=±π4\alpha=\pm\frac{\pi}{4}α=±4π​. τ12=σ2−σ12\tau_{12}=\frac{\sigma_2-\sigma_1}{2}τ12​=2σ2​−σ1​​, τ13=σ3−σ12\tau_{13}=\frac{\sigma_3-\sigma_1}{2}τ13​=2σ3​−σ1​​ etc.

Differential Equations of Equilibrium

As stress moves from point to pointn in an elastic body, it must satisfy the equilibrium equations.

In the equations above, a taylor expansion f(x+Δx)=f(x0)+Δx(dfdx∣xc)+0x2f(x+\Delta{x})=f(x_0)+\Delta{x}(\frac{df}{dx}|_{x_c})+0x^2f(x+Δx)=f(x0​)+Δx(dxdf​∣xc​​)+0x2 shows the stress on a side starting at x0x_0x0​ and ending at xcx_cxc​, ignoring second order effects. The force balance between these is shown below:

ΔxΔyΔz[∂σx∂x+∂σy∂y+∂σz∂z+β+0(Δx+Δy+Δz)]=0(EE)\Delta{x}\Delta{y}\Delta{z}[\frac{\partial{\sigma_x}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_y}}{\partial{y}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_z}}{\partial{z}}+\beta+0(\Delta{x}+\Delta{y}+\Delta{z})]=0\tag{EE} ΔxΔyΔz[∂x∂σx​​+∂y∂σy​​+∂z∂σz​​+β+0(Δx+Δy+Δz)]=0(EE)

When divided by ΔxΔyΔz\Delta{x}\Delta{y}\Delta{z}ΔxΔyΔz and lim⁡Δx,Δy,Δz→0\lim_{\Delta{x},\Delta{y},\Delta{z}\to{0}}limΔx,Δy,Δz→0​, we have:

∂σx∂x+∂σy∂y+∂σz∂z+β=0(E at Point)\frac{\partial{\sigma_x}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_y}}{\partial{y}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_z}}{\partial{z}}+\beta=0\tag{E at Point} ∂x∂σx​​+∂y∂σy​​+∂z∂σz​​+β=0(E at Point)

The E at Point equation is at a point, such that all points in the body holds. We can then establish this in terms of components:

∂σxx∂x+∂σxy∂y+∂σxz∂z+βx=0(Navier 1)\frac{\partial{\sigma_{xx}}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{xy}}}{\partial{y}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{xz}}}{\partial{z}}+\beta_x=0\tag{Navier 1} ∂x∂σxx​​+∂y∂σxy​​+∂z∂σxz​​+βx​=0(Navier 1)

∂σxy∂x+∂σyy∂y+∂σyz∂z+βy=0(Navier 2)\frac{\partial{\sigma_{xy}}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{yy}}}{\partial{y}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{yz}}}{\partial{z}}+\beta_y=0\tag{Navier 2} ∂x∂σxy​​+∂y∂σyy​​+∂z∂σyz​​+βy​=0(Navier 2)

∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y+∂σzz∂z+βz=0(Navier 3)\frac{\partial{\sigma_{xz}}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{yz}}}{\partial{y}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{zz}}}{\partial{z}}+\beta_z=0\tag{Navier 3} ∂x∂σxz​​+∂y∂σyz​​+∂z∂σzz​​+βz​=0(Navier 3)

Since these have 6 unknowns and 3 equations, they are related to the strain-stress equations

Stress-Strain Relations

The below shows the displacement vector, with u, v, and w components:

In the 1D case, we can see the extension of a bar below:

The extensional strain along x is ε=Δx∗−ΔxΔx\varepsilon=\frac{\Delta{x^*}-\Delta{x}}{\Delta{x}}ε=ΔxΔx∗−Δx​, and the displatement of point a u(x)=x∗−xu(x)=x^*-xu(x)=x∗−x. To consider both displacements, displacement of point b u(x+Δx)=(x∗+Δx∗)−(x+Δx)=u(x)+εΔxu(x+\Delta{x})=(x^*+\Delta{x^*})-(x+\Delta{x})=u(x)+\varepsilon{\Delta{x}}u(x+Δx)=(x∗+Δx∗)−(x+Δx)=u(x)+εΔx. For a small Δx\Delta{x}Δx, u(x+Δx)=u(x)+Δxdudx+0(Δx)2u(x+\Delta{x})=u(x)+\Delta{x}\frac{du}{dx}+0(\Delta{x})^2u(x+Δx)=u(x)+Δxdxdu​+0(Δx)2, or the deformation at ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Undefined control sequence: \* at position 3: A^\̲*̲ plus the deformation between A->B times the linear rate of deformation. Thus, ε=u(x+Δx)−u(x)Δx\varepsilon=\frac{u(x+\Delta{x})-u(x)}{\Delta{x}}ε=Δxu(x+Δx)−u(x)​. Subbing in values, and letting Δx→0\Delta{x}\to{0}Δx→0, we have:

εx=dudx(Extensional Strain 1)\varepsilon_x=\frac{du}{dx}\tag{Extensional Strain 1} εx​=dxdu​(Extensional Strain 1)

In the 2D Case, we have the below:

The below can be observed from this:

εxx=A∗B∗−ABAB\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{A^{*} B^{*}-AB}{AB} εxx​=ABA∗B∗−AB​

εxy=π2−β2\varepsilon_{xy}=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\beta}{2} εxy​=22π​−β​

These, as well as the 3D case, can be simplified to similar conclusions as the 1D case.

εxx=∂u∂x\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{x}} εxx​=∂x∂u​

εyy=∂v∂y\varepsilon_{yy}=\frac{\partial{v}}{\partial{y}} εyy​=∂y∂v​

εzz=∂w∂z\varepsilon_{zz}=\frac{\partial{w}}{\partial{z}} εzz​=∂z∂w​

εxy=∂u∂y+∂v∂x2\varepsilon_{xy}=\frac{\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{y}}+\frac{\partial{v}}{\partial{x}}}{2} εxy​=2∂y∂u​+∂x∂v​​

The strain tensor is symmetric, as is the stress tensor.

(ε)=(εxxεxyεxzεyxεyyεyzεzxεzyεzz)(\varepsilon)= \begin{pmatrix} \varepsilon_{xx} & \varepsilon_{xy} & \varepsilon_{xz} \\ \varepsilon_{yx} & \varepsilon_{yy} & \varepsilon_{yz} \\ \varepsilon_{zx} & \varepsilon_{zy} & \varepsilon_{zz} \\ \end{pmatrix}(ε)=⎝⎛​εxx​εyx​εzx​​εxy​εyy​εzy​​εxz​εyz​εzz​​⎠⎞​

Hooke's Law

To solve for the equilibrium equations EE1,2,3; Navier's equation is formulated. This can be solved using finite element analysis, sophisticated analytical approaches (potential theory), boundary element analysis. These are difficult; 60% of standard engineering problems are simplified. Research in solid mechanics is centred on methods to solve Navier's equations.

To find combatibility conditions for strain, one is wondering if a strain field is real or not. If it is real, it must satisfy combatibility equations. Since ∂2εxx∂y2=∂2∂y2∂u∂x\frac{\partial^2{\varepsilon_{xx}}}{\partial{y^2}}=\frac{\partial^2}{\partial{y^2}}\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{x}}∂y2∂2εxx​​=∂y2∂2​∂x∂u​, ∂2εyy∂x2=∂2∂x2∂v∂y\frac{\partial^2{\varepsilon_{yy}}}{\partial{x^2}}=\frac{\partial^2}{\partial{x^2}}\frac{\partial{v}}{\partial{y}}∂x2∂2εyy​​=∂x2∂2​∂y∂v​ and 2∂2εxy∂x∂y=∂2∂x∂y(∂v∂x+∂u∂y)2\frac{\partial^2{\varepsilon_{xy}}}{\partial{x}\partial{y}}=\frac{\partial^2}{\partial{x}\partial{y}}(\frac{\partial{v}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{y}})2∂x∂y∂2εxy​​=∂x∂y∂2​(∂x∂v​+∂y∂u​), we have:

2∂2εxy∂x∂y=∂2εxx∂y2+∂2εyy∂x2(Combatibility)2\frac{\partial^2{\varepsilon_{xy}}}{\partial{x}\partial{y}}=\frac{\partial^2{\varepsilon_{xx}}}{\partial{y^2}}+\frac{\partial^2{\varepsilon_{yy}}}{\partial{x^2}}\tag{Combatibility} 2∂x∂y∂2εxy​​=∂y2∂2εxx​​+∂x2∂2εyy​​(Combatibility)

Hooke's Law has several assumptions:

  • linear elastic deformation
  • homogeneous (elastic properties do not change from point to point)
  • isotropic (relation between stress and strain is the same no matter which axes are used). Hence, relation between σxx,σxy,σyy\sigma_{xx},\sigma_{xy},\sigma_{yy}σxx​,σxy​,σyy​ and εxx,εxy,εyy\varepsilon_{xx},\varepsilon_{xy},\varepsilon_{yy}εxx​,εxy​,εyy​ are the same as σXX,σXY,σYY\sigma_{XX},\sigma_{XY},\sigma_{YY}σXX​,σXY​,σYY​ and εXX,εXY,εYY\varepsilon_{XX},\varepsilon_{XY},\varepsilon_{YY}εXX​,εXY​,εYY​. Steel is isotropic and homogeneous, concrete is anisotropic and nonhomogeneous

Under uniaxial strain, εxx=σxxL\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{L}εxx​=Lσxx​​. This stress is accompanied by lateral contractions associated with strain εyy\varepsilon_{yy}εyy​ and εzz\varepsilon_{zz}εzz​. Due to isotropic assumption, εyy=εzz\varepsilon_{yy}=\varepsilon_{zz}εyy​=εzz​. Experiments show that for a small εxx\varepsilon_{xx}εxx​, the ratios εyyεxx\frac{\varepsilon_{yy}}{\varepsilon_{xx}}εxx​εyy​​ and εzzεxx\frac{\varepsilon_{zz}}{\varepsilon_{xx}}εxx​εzz​​ are constant and negative (most of the time). Thus, see below:

εyy=εzz=−νεxx=−νσxxE(Poisson Ratio)\varepsilon_{yy}=\varepsilon_{zz}=-\nu\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{-\nu\sigma_{xx}}{E}\tag{Poisson Ratio} εyy​=εzz​=−νεxx​=E−νσxx​​(Poisson Ratio)

Similarly, application of stress in y direction causes strain in x and z, and stress in z direction causes stress in x and y. Without shear, we have the below:

εxx=σxx−ν(σyy+σzz)E\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{\sigma_{xx}-\nu{(\sigma_{yy}+\sigma_{zz})}}{E} εxx​=Eσxx​−ν(σyy​+σzz​)​

εyy=σyy−ν(σxx+σzz)E\varepsilon_{yy}=\frac{\sigma_{yy}-\nu{(\sigma_{xx}+\sigma_{zz})}}{E} εyy​=Eσyy​−ν(σxx​+σzz​)​

εzz=σzz−ν(σxx+σyy)E\varepsilon_{zz}=\frac{\sigma_{zz}-\nu{(\sigma_{xx}+\sigma_{yy})}}{E} εzz​=Eσzz​−ν(σxx​+σyy​)​

By inverting the system we find:

σxx=μεxx+λ(εxx+εyy+εzz)\sigma_{xx}=\mu\varepsilon_{xx}+\lambda{(\varepsilon_{xx}+\varepsilon_{yy}+\varepsilon_{zz})} σxx​=μεxx​+λ(εxx​+εyy​+εzz​)

σyy=μεyy+λ(εxx+εyy+εzz)\sigma_{yy}=\mu\varepsilon_{yy}+\lambda{(\varepsilon_{xx}+\varepsilon_{yy}+\varepsilon_{zz})} σyy​=μεyy​+λ(εxx​+εyy​+εzz​)

σzz=μεzz+λ(εxx+εyy+εzz)\sigma_{zz}=\mu\varepsilon_{zz}+\lambda{(\varepsilon_{xx}+\varepsilon_{yy}+\varepsilon_{zz})} σzz​=μεzz​+λ(εxx​+εyy​+εzz​)

The constants, μ\muμ and λ\lambdaλ, are defined below:

μ=E1+ν=2G\mu=\frac{E}{1+\nu}=2G μ=1+νE​=2G

λ=νE(1+ν)(1−2ν)\lambda=\frac{\nu{E}}{(1+\nu)(1-2\nu)} λ=(1+ν)(1−2ν)νE​

Experimentally, it was found that shear deformation can only be produced by plane stresses. Thus,

εxy=σxy2G\varepsilon_{xy}=\frac{\sigma_{xy}}{2G} εxy​=2Gσxy​​

εxz=σxz2G\varepsilon_{xz}=\frac{\sigma_{xz}}{2G} εxz​=2Gσxz​​

εyz=σyz2G\varepsilon_{yz}=\frac{\sigma_{yz}}{2G} εyz​=2Gσyz​​

The stresses and strains can be related to displacement. See Example

Volumetric Strain can be found by dividing new dimensions by old dimensions.

εV=V∗−VV=x∗y∗z∗−xyzxyz=(1+εxx)(1+εyy)(1+εzz)−xyzxyz≈εxx+εyy+εzz=(1−2ν)(σxx+σyy+σzz)E\varepsilon_{V}=\frac{V^*-V}{V}=\frac{x^*y^*z^*-xyz}{xyz}=\frac{(1+\varepsilon_{xx})(1+\varepsilon_{yy})(1+\varepsilon_{zz})-xyz}{xyz}\approx{\varepsilon_{xx}+\varepsilon_{yy}+\varepsilon_{zz}}=\frac{(1-2\nu)(\sigma_{xx}+\sigma_{yy}+\sigma_{zz})}{E} εV​=VV∗−V​=xyzx∗y∗z∗−xyz​=xyz(1+εxx​)(1+εyy​)(1+εzz​)−xyz​≈εxx​+εyy​+εzz​=E(1−2ν)(σxx​+σyy​+σzz​)​

Failure Criteria

Metals have a linear elastic response until a certain value of stress.

Plasticity is a vast and complicated subject, with failure criteria not being universal. Tresca, Von Mises, and St. Venant work well for crystalline and polycrystalline materials (Steel is crystalline, or perfect order ion; and Aluminum is polycrystalline, or approximately perfect ion order). For amorphous materials, such as glass, synthetic polymers, and rubber, failure criteria don't work

τy=∣max⁡[σ1−σ2∣σ1−σ3∣σ2−σ3]∣2(Tresca Criterion)\tau_y=\frac{|\max{[\sigma_1-\sigma_2|\sigma_1-\sigma_3|\sigma_2-\sigma_3]}|}{2}\tag{Tresca Criterion} τy​=2∣max[σ1​−σ2​∣σ1​−σ3​∣σ2​−σ3​]∣​(Tresca Criterion)

The slip along occurs along crystallographic planes, and results in overall shear deformation. When $\tau_{max}=\tau_y, yielding will occur through slippage parallel to the shear stress. See tresca example here

The Von Mises Criterion is another popular criterion for ductile materials. See proof here and equation below:

(σ1−σ2)2+(σ2−σ3)2+(σ1−σ3)2=2σy2(Von Mises)(\sigma_1-\sigma_2)^2+(\sigma_2-\sigma_3)^2+(\sigma_1-\sigma_3)^2=2\sigma_y^2\tag{Von Mises} (σ1​−σ2​)2+(σ2​−σ3​)2+(σ1​−σ3​)2=2σy2​(Von Mises)

For plane stress, we have the following:

(σ1σy)2+(σ2σy)2−σ1σ2σy2=1(Plane Von Mises)(\frac{\sigma_1}{\sigma_y})^2+(\frac{\sigma_2}{\sigma_y})^2-\frac{\sigma_1\sigma_2}{\sigma_y^2}=1\tag{Plane Von Mises} (σy​σ1​​)2+(σy​σ2​​)2−σy2​σ1​σ2​​=1(Plane Von Mises)

The Von Mises criterion is visualized with an ellipse. Parts on the ellipse that touch the axis indicate that the material is yielding.

For concrete, there are a few other approaches to determine failure. Micropolar elasticity, homogenization of material to an equivalent material, and Rankine are used. Rankine is also commonly used for ceramics

Torsion

Torsion of cylindrical bars

If beam is long enough and applied torque is small, every cross section of the bar parallel to generators will behave in the same way.

Based on experimental evidence, the amount of rotation of any section will depend on its distance from the fixed end. Thus, angle of twist α\alphaα and angle of twist per unit length θ\thetaθ are related by:

α=θz\alpha=\theta{z} α=θz

A point of origin to point P is the radius vector. If α\alphaα is small, OP≈OP′OP\approx{OP\prime}OP≈OP′, sin⁡α≈α\sin\alpha\approx{\alpha}sinα≈α, and cos⁡α≈1\cos\alpha\approx{1}cosα≈1. Thus, we have:

x=rcos⁡βx=r\cos\beta x=rcosβ

y=rsin⁡βy=r\sin\beta y=rsinβ

We can see that u=rcos⁡(β+α)−rcos⁡βu=r\cos{(\beta+\alpha)}-r\cos\betau=rcos(β+α)−rcosβ. This simplifies to u=rcos⁡αcos⁡β−rsin⁡αsin⁡β−rcos⁡βu=r\cos\alpha\cos\beta-r\sin\alpha\sin\beta-r\cos\betau=rcosαcosβ−rsinαsinβ−rcosβ. Using out approximations, we see that u≈−rαsin⁡βu\approx{-r\alpha\sin\beta}u≈−rαsinβ. Similarly, we have rsin⁡(β+α)−rsin⁡β=rsin⁡αcos⁡β+rcos⁡αsin⁡β−rsin⁡β≈rαcos⁡βr\sin{(\beta+\alpha)}-r\sin\beta=r\sin\alpha\cos\beta+r\cos\alpha\sin\beta-r\sin\beta\approx{r\alpha\cos\beta}rsin(β+α)−rsinβ=rsinαcosβ+rcosαsinβ−rsinβ≈rαcosβ. We have the following:

u≈−αy=−θyzu\approx{-\alpha{y}}=-\theta{yz} u≈−αy=−θyz

v≈αx=θxzv\approx{\alpha{x}}=\theta{xz} v≈αx=θxz

The warping function ω(x,y)\omega (x,y)ω(x,y) describes the torsional warp. The displacement is a function of it

w=θω(x,y)≈0w=\theta\omega{(x,y)}\approx{0} w=θω(x,y)≈0

To check if this is combatible, we ask:

  • Does ω(y)\omega{(y)}ω(y) exist?
  • Does ω(x,y)\omega{(x,y)}ω(x,y) exist for displacement field, and result in stresses combatible for given boundary condition?

We know:

  • lateral surface is free from load
  • resultant distribution of stresses is equivalent to a couple applied at the end z=Lz=Lz=L
  • at the end z=Lz=Lz=L, resultant force vanishes

We can also use strains relations for torsion. Since u isn't a function of x, v isn't a function of y, and w isn't a function of z, we have εxx=εyy=εzz=εxy=0\varepsilon_{xx}=\varepsilon_{yy}=\varepsilon_{zz}=\varepsilon_{xy}=0εxx​=εyy​=εzz​=εxy​=0. We also have:

εxz=−θ(∂ω∂x−y)2\varepsilon_{xz}=\frac{-\theta{(\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial_{x}}-y)}}{2} εxz​=2−θ(∂x​∂ω​−y)​

εyz=θ(∂ω∂y+x)2\varepsilon_{yz}=\frac{\theta{(\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial_{y}}+x)}}{2} εyz​=2θ(∂y​∂ω​+x)​

Thus, there is pure shear. All stresses are zero except for the following:

σxz=Eεxz1+ν\sigma_{xz}=\frac{E\varepsilon_{xz}}{1+\nu} σxz​=1+νEεxz​​

σyz=Eεyz1+ν\sigma_{yz}=\frac{E\varepsilon_{yz}}{1+\nu} σyz​=1+νEεyz​​

By the equilibrium equations, we have Laplaces equation:

∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y=∂2ω(x,y)∂x2+∂2ω(x,y)∂y2=∇2ω(x,y)=0(Laplace)\frac{\partial\sigma_{xz}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial\sigma_{yz}}{\partial{y}}=\frac{\partial^2\omega{(x,y)}}{\partial_{x^2}}+\frac{\partial^2\omega{(x,y)}}{\partial_{y^2}}=\nabla^2\omega{(x,y)}=0\tag{Laplace} ∂x∂σxz​​+∂y∂σyz​​=∂x2​∂2ω(x,y)​+∂y2​∂2ω(x,y)​=∇2ω(x,y)=0(Laplace)

  • ∇2=(∂2∂x2+∂2∂y2)\nabla^2 = (\frac{\partial^2}{\partial_{x^2}}+\frac{\partial^2}{\partial_{y^2}})∇2=(∂x2​∂2​+∂y2​∂2​)

Within the beam's cross-section, Laplace's equation must be satisfied. Solved with Fourier's Method of Separation.

Another boundary condition comes from the stresses. Since there is no load, σN⃗=0\vec{\sigma_N}=0σN​​=0. Since σx⃗=σxzk⃗\vec{\sigma_x}=\sigma_{xz}\vec{k}σx​​=σxz​k and σy⃗=σyzk⃗\vec{\sigma_y}=\sigma_{yz}\vec{k}σy​​=σyz​k, we have the following:

σN⃗=k⃗(σxzNx+σyzNy)=0\vec{\sigma_N}=\vec{k}(\sigma_{xz}N_x+\sigma_{yz}N_y)=0 σN​​=k(σxz​Nx​+σyz​Ny​)=0

Plugging in the formulas for σ\sigmaσ, we have:

Nx∂ω∂x+Ny∂ω∂y=yNx−xNy(Neumann Condition)N_x\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial_x}+N_y\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial_y}=yN_x-xN_y\tag{Neumann Condition} Nx​∂x​∂ω​+Ny​∂y​∂ω​=yNx​−xNy​(Neumann Condition)

Simplified, ∂ϕ∂n=yNx−xNy\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial_n}=yN_x-xN_y∂n​∂ϕ​=yNx​−xNy​ for dS. This normal derivative equation is true for any arbitrary x-section. From this, the torsional constant, polar moment of inertia, and torsional rigidity derivation are found.

If circular bar, no warping is a fair assumption. Plugging this into laplaces equation, 0=0

We know that σxz\sigma_{xz}σxz​ and σyz\sigma_{yz}σyz​ are functions of x and y only and ∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y=0\frac{\partial{\sigma_{xz}}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{\sigma_{yz}}}{\partial{y}}=0∂x∂σxz​​+∂y∂σyz​​=0. Also, we know that for a vector field F⃗=P(x,y,z)i^+Q(x,y,z)j^+R(x,y,z)k^\vec{F}=P(x,y,z)\hat{i}+Q(x,y,z)\hat{j}+R(x,y,z)\hat{k}F=P(x,y,z)i^+Q(x,y,z)j^​+R(x,y,z)k^ with continuous first partial derivatives in domain D, if there exists a function ϕ(x,y,z)\phi{(x,y,z)}ϕ(x,y,z) in D such that ∇ϕ=F⃗\nabla\phi=\vec{F}∇ϕ=F, then ∇×F⃗=0⃗\nabla\times{\vec{F}}=\vec{0}∇×F=0. Conversely, if D is simply connected (no holes) and ∇×F⃗=0⃗\nabla\times{\vec{F}}=\vec{0}∇×F=0, then there exists a function ϕ(x,y,z)\phi{(x,y,z)}ϕ(x,y,z) in D usch that ∇ϕ=F⃗\nabla\phi=\vec{F}∇ϕ=F. Note the below:

∇=[∂∂x∂∂y∂∂z]\nabla=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial}{\partial{x}}\\ \frac{\partial}{\partial{y}}\\ \frac{\partial}{\partial{z}} \end{bmatrix}∇=⎣⎡​∂x∂​∂y∂​∂z∂​​⎦⎤​

From this, we have Prandtl stress functions:

σxz=∂ϕ(x,y)∂y(Prandtl Stress function)\sigma_{xz}=\frac{\partial\phi{(x,y)}}{\partial{y}}\tag{Prandtl Stress function} σxz​=∂y∂ϕ(x,y)​(Prandtl Stress function)

σyz=−∂ϕ(x,y)∂x(Prandtl Stress function)\sigma_{yz}=-\frac{\partial\phi{(x,y)}}{\partial{x}}\tag{Prandtl Stress function} σyz​=−∂x∂ϕ(x,y)​(Prandtl Stress function)

From this Prandtl stress function, we have:

∂σxz∂x+∂σyz∂y=∂2ϕ∂x∂y−∂2ϕ∂y∂x=0\frac{\partial\sigma_{xz}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial\sigma_{yz}}{\partial{y}}=\frac{\partial^2\phi}{\partial{x}\partial{y}}-\frac{\partial^2\phi}{\partial{y}\partial{x}}=0 ∂x∂σxz​​+∂y∂σyz​​=∂x∂y∂2ϕ​−∂y∂x∂2ϕ​=0

Since εxz=σxz2G\varepsilon_{xz}=\frac{\sigma_{xz}}{2G}εxz​=2Gσxz​​ and ∂εxz∂y−∂εyz∂x=−α\frac{\partial\varepsilon_{xz}}{\partial{y}}-\frac{\partial\varepsilon_{yz}}{\partial{x}}=-\alpha∂y∂εxz​​−∂x∂εyz​​=−α (derivation page 49), we have:

∂2ϕ∂x2+∂2ϕ∂y2=−2Gα(Poisson’s Equation)\frac{\partial^2\phi}{\partial{x^2}}+\frac{\partial^2\phi}{\partial{y^2}}=-2G\alpha\tag{Poisson's Equation} ∂x2∂2ϕ​+∂y2∂2ϕ​=−2Gα(Poisson’s Equation)

There is also boundary conditions to consider. See cross section below:

In this, x(s) and y(s) are parametric coordinates of the curve and dx is tangential to the boundary. With s representing arclength, dx=dsdx=dsdx=ds. We can write x as a function of arclength:

x=x(s)i+y(s)jx=x(s)i+y(s)j x=x(s)i+y(s)j

In other words, terms of theta are replaced with terms of s. We can further express this into a unit tangent, t, in the direction of increasing s. See below:

dx=dxi+dyj=(dxdsi+dydsj)ds=t(s)dsdx=dxi+dyj=(\frac{dx}{ds}i+\frac{dy}{ds}j)ds=t(s)ds dx=dxi+dyj=(dsdx​i+dsdy​j)ds=t(s)ds

Since the tangent is the slope of the boundary, t=dxdsi+dydsjt=\frac{dx}{ds}i+\frac{dy}{ds}jt=dsdx​i+dsdy​j. Also, since it is perpendicular to the k and radial unit vectors, we can express t as a unit vector varying with theta. See below:

t=k⃗×er⃗=eθt=\vec{k}\times{\vec{e_r}}=e_{\theta} t=k×er​​=eθ​

The normal component is perpendicular to both t and k. Thus, we have:

N=t×k=(dxdsi+dydsj)×kN=t\times{k}=(\frac{dx}{ds}i+\frac{dy}{ds}j)\times{k} N=t×k=(dsdx​i+dsdy​j)×k

Since N=Nxi+NyjN=N_xi+N_yjN=Nx​i+Ny​j, we can say:

Nx=dydsN_x=\frac{dy}{ds} Nx​=dsdy​

Ny=−dxdsN_y=-\frac{dx}{ds} Ny​=−dsdx​

Torque

We know that at the end of the bar, σN=σz\sigma_N=\sigma_zσN​=σz​. Thus the resultant force is F=∬σzdAF=\iint{\sigma_{z}dA}F=∬σz​dA. Because σzx\sigma_{zx}σzx​ is the i component and σzy\sigma_{zy}σzy​ is the j component. We have:

F=∬(∂ϕ∂yi−∂ϕ∂xj)dA=i∬∂ϕ∂ydxdy−j∬∂ϕ∂xdxdyF=\iint{(\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}i-\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}j)dA}=i\iint{\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}dxdy}-j\iint{\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}dxdy} F=∬(∂y∂ϕ​i−∂x∂ϕ​j)dA=i∬∂y∂ϕ​dxdy−j∬∂x∂ϕ​dxdy

Torque is defined below:

T=∬(xi+yi)×(σzxi+σzyj)dA=−∬(x∂ϕ∂x+y∂ϕ∂y)dAT=\iint{(xi+yi)\times{(\sigma_{zx}i+\sigma_{zy}j)}dA}=-\iint{(x\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}+y\frac{\partial{\phi}}{\partial{y}})dA} T=∬(xi+yi)×(σzx​i+σzy​j)dA=−∬(x∂x∂ϕ​+y∂y∂ϕ​)dA

By green's theorum, we can show the following (derivation page 57):

T=2∬ϕ(x,y)dxdyT=2\iint{\phi{(x,y)}dxdy} T=2∬ϕ(x,y)dxdy

Prandtl's Soap-Film Analogy

If a function satisfies the boundary condition, but not Poisson's equaiton, solved with separation of variables and Fourier series method. (Chou and Pagano, 6.5)

In the soap solution, a film under lateral pressure will deflect. Similar to bubbles

For small deflections, the equation for the shape z(x,y) of the soap film is the following:

∂2z∂x2+∂2z∂y2=−pS\frac{\partial^2{z}}{\partial{x^2}}+\frac{\partial^2{z}}{\partial{y^2}}=-\frac{p}{S} ∂x2∂2z​+∂y2∂2z​=−Sp​

  • z=0z=0z=0 on the boundary, p is pressure, S is the surface tension

This is similar to torsion because it satisfies Poisson's Equation and the boundary condition (See here for proof)

z(x,y)=p2GαSϕ(x,y)z(x,y)=\frac{p}{2G\alpha{S}}\phi{(x,y)} z(x,y)=2GαSp​ϕ(x,y)

This condition requires that the boundary of the soap-film has the same shape as the boundary of the cross-section in the torsion problem. From this, we get the following, with c=2GαSp>0c=\frac{2G\alpha{S}}{p}>0c=p2GαS​>0:

σxz=∂ϕ∂y=c∂z∂y\sigma_{xz}=\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}=c\frac{\partial{z}}{\partial{y}} σxz​=∂y∂ϕ​=c∂y∂z​

σyz=−∂ϕ∂x=−c∂z∂x\sigma_{yz}=-\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}=-c\frac{\partial{z}}{\partial{x}} σyz​=−∂x∂ϕ​=−c∂x∂z​

σz=σxzi+σyzk=c(∂z∂yi−∂zpartialxj)\sigma_z=\sigma_{xz}i+\sigma_{yz}k=c(\frac{\partial{z}}{\partial{y}}i-\frac{\partial{z}}{partial{x}}j) σz​=σxz​i+σyz​k=c(∂y∂z​i−partialx∂z​j)

τ=∣σz∣=σxz2+σyz2=c(∂z∂x)2+(∂z∂y)2\tau=|\sigma_z|=\sqrt{\sigma_{xz}^2+\sigma_{yz}^2}=c\sqrt{(\frac{\partial{z}}{\partial{x}})^2+(\frac{\partial{z}}{\partial{y}})^2} τ=∣σz​∣=σxz2​+σyz2​​=c(∂x∂z​)2+(∂y∂z​)2​

From this, we know that the maximum τ\tauτ corresponds to the maximum slopes in the soap-film problem

We can also rerwite the equation for torsion. This is the volume under pressurized soap film. See below:

T=2c∬zdxdyT=2c\iint{zdxdy} T=2c∬zdxdy

Examples with narrow rectangular component of n are found here

Multiply Connected Cross Sections

Multiply Connected: ross-sections with holes that don't have stress on hole boundaries

ϕ\phiϕ is a constant on each hole boundary, and is different for each hole. We also know that ∂2ϕ∂x2+∂2ϕ∂y2=−2Gα\frac{\partial^2\phi}{\partial{x^2}}+\frac{\partial^2\phi}{\partial{y^2}}=-2G\alpha∂x2∂2ϕ​+∂y2∂2ϕ​=−2Gα in the shaded portion (not hole) and ∂ϕ∂s=0\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{s}}=0∂s∂ϕ​=0 at the holes

We know ω(x(L),y(L))=ω(x(0),y(0))+∫0Ldωdsds\omega{(x(L),y(L))}=\omega{(x(0),y(0))}+\int_0^L{\frac{d\omega}{ds}ds}ω(x(L),y(L))=ω(x(0),y(0))+∫0L​dsdω​ds. Since ωL=ω0\omega_L=\omega_0ωL​=ω0​, we know ∮dω=0\oint{d\omega}=0∮dω=0. We then have:

∮(∂ω∂xdx+∂ω∂ydy)=0\oint{(\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial{x}}dx+\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial{y}}dy)}=0 ∮(∂x∂ω​dx+∂y∂ω​dy)=0

Since σxz=Gα(∂ω∂x−y)\sigma_{xz}=G\alpha{(\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial{x}}-y)}σxz​=Gα(∂x∂ω​−y) and σyz=Gα(∂ω∂y+x)\sigma_{yz}=G\alpha{(\frac{\partial\omega}{\partial{y}}+x)}σyz​=Gα(∂y∂ω​+x), and σxz=∂ϕ∂y\sigma_{xz}=\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}σxz​=∂y∂ϕ​ and σyz=−∂ϕ∂x\sigma_{yz}=-\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}σyz​=−∂x∂ϕ​, it can be rearranged in terms of ϕ\phiϕ. We have:

∮B1(∂ϕ∂ydx−∂ϕ∂xdy)Gα+∮B1ydx−ydy=0\frac{\oint_{B1}{(\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}dx-\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}dy)}}{G\alpha}+\oint_{B1}{ydx-ydy}=0 Gα∮B1​(∂y∂ϕ​dx−∂x∂ϕ​dy)​+∮B1​ydx−ydy=0

From Green's Theorum, we can say:

∮B1(xdy−ydx)=∬A1∂x∂x+∂y∂ydA=2A1\oint_{B1}(xdy-ydx)=\iint_{A1}{\frac{\partial{x}}{\partial{x}}+\frac{\partial{y}}{\partial{y}}}dA=2A_1 ∮B1​(xdy−ydx)=∬A1​∂x∂x​+∂y∂y​dA=2A1​

As a result, ∮B1(∂ϕ∂ydx−∂ϕ∂xdy)=2GαA1\oint_{B1}(\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}dx-\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}dy)=2G\alpha{A_1}∮B1​(∂y∂ϕ​dx−∂x∂ϕ​dy)=2GαA1​.

Since x(s) and y(s) are parametric equations of hole 1, Nx∗=dydsN_x^*=\frac{dy}{ds}Nx∗​=dsdy​ and Ny∗=−dxdsN_y^*=-\frac{dx}{ds}Ny∗​=−dsdx​ away from the hole. Into the hole, we have Nx=dydsN_x=\frac{dy}{ds}Nx​=dsdy​ and Ny=dxdsN_y=\frac{dx}{ds}Ny​=dsdx​. Thus, dx=Nydsdx=N_ydsdx=Ny​ds and dy=−Nxdsdy=-N_xdsdy=−Nx​ds. From this, ∂ϕ∂ydx−∂ϕ∂xdx=0−N⋅∇ϕds\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{y}}dx-\frac{\partial\phi}{\partial{x}}dx=0-N\cdot{\nabla\phi{ds}}∂y∂ϕ​dx−∂x∂ϕ​dx=0−N⋅∇ϕds.

N⋅∇ϕN\cdot{\nabla\phi}N⋅∇ϕ is derivative along direction N or directional derivative

Therefore, ∮B1N⋅∇ϕds=2GαA1\oint_{B1}N\cdot{\nabla\phi{ds}}=2G\alpha{A_1}∮B1​N⋅∇ϕds=2GαA1​. For n holes, we have:

T=2∬AmϕdA+2∑i=1nϕiAiT=2\iint_{A_m}\phi{dA}+2\sum_{i=1}^n\phi_iA_i T=2∬Am​​ϕdA+2i=1∑n​ϕi​Ai​

For thin walls, we have:

T=2∑i=1nϕiAiT=2\sum_{i=1}^n\phi_iA_i T=2i=1∑n​ϕi​Ai​

With the soap-film analogy, a weightless plate is assumed at hole. This, the volume under the soap-film is expressed with the following:

V=∬Amz(x,y)dA+∑i=1nziAiV=\iint_{A_m}z(x,y)dA+\sum_{i=1}^nz_iA_i V=∬Am​​z(x,y)dA+i=1∑n​zi​Ai​

For a thin wall (hole area is much larger by area occupied by material), we know that Prandtl's function ϕ\phiϕ is ery at outer boundary, and is ϕh\phi_hϕh​ in middle. If thickness changes with arclength, t(s)=dxdsi+dydsj=Nyi−Nxjt(s)=\frac{dx}{ds}i+\frac{dy}{ds}j=N_yi-N_xjt(s)=dsdx​i+dsdy​j=Ny​i−Nx​j. The volume is approximately equal to zhAhz_hA_hzh​Ah​

Slope n⋅Δzn\cdot\Delta{z}n⋅Δz should be constant, and equal to zht(s)\frac{z_h}{t(s)}t(s)zh​​. By the analogy, n⋅Δϕ≈ϕht(s)n\cdot\Delta\phi\approx\frac{\phi_h}{t(s)}n⋅Δϕ≈t(s)ϕh​​

Derivation further shown here. We then have:

∮Bhτds=2GαAh\oint_{B_h}{\tau{ds}}=2G\alpha{A_h} ∮Bh​​τds=2GαAh​

ϕˉ=ϕh2\bar{\phi}=\frac{\phi_h}{2}ϕˉ​=2ϕh​​. With this, we can say that T=2∬AmϕdA+2ϕhAh→2ϕˉAm+2ϕhAhT=2\iint_{A_m}\phi{dA}+2\phi_hA_h\to 2\bar\phi{A_m}+2\phi_h{A_h}T=2∬Am​​ϕdA+2ϕh​Ah​→2ϕˉ​Am​+2ϕh​Ah​. For very thin walled sections, A≈AhA\approx{A_h}A≈Ah​.

We then have 2GαAh=∮τds=ϕh∮dst(s)=T2A∮dst(s)2G\alpha{A_h}=\oint\tau{ds}=\phi_h\oint\frac{ds}{t(s)}=\frac{T}{2A}\oint\frac{ds}{t(s)}2GαAh​=∮τds=ϕh​∮t(s)ds​=2AT​∮t(s)ds​

Then, α=T4GA2∮dst(s)\alpha=\frac{T}{4GA^2}\oint\frac{ds}{t(s)}α=4GA2T​∮t(s)ds​. If t(s)=t is a constant, α=Tl4GA2t\alpha=\frac{Tl}{4GA^2t}α=4GA2tTl​, with l being the arclength.

Thus, T=GJαT=GJ\alphaT=GJα. In general, J=4A2∮dst(s)J=\frac{4A^2}{\oint\frac{ds}{t(s)}}J=∮t(s)ds​4A2​. if t is constant, J=4A2tlJ=\frac{4A^2t}{l}J=l4A2t​

Plate Theory

There are three major theories based on this assumption: beam theory,

  • Beam Theory: if assuming beam is very slender. Long, slender beams are able to carry transverse load due to bending; causes deflection and stress resultants and buckling.
  • Plate Theory: plate is considered thin if ha≪1\frac{h}{a}\ll{1}ah​≪1 and hl0≪1\frac{h}{l_0}\ll{1}l0​h​≪1. Having thin walls greatly simplifies problem.
  • Shell Theory: thickness of bottle negligible to surface area

For a plate, when force is applied, there will be:

  • Moment about the x and y axis
  • Twisting moment about the xy plane
  • Two shear forces

For a beam, w(x) is about the neutral axis. For a plate, midsurface is the neutral axis. Thus, deflection is deflection of the midsurface. Only small deflections considered to stay within the linear theory assumptions

Buckling for plates is not as straightforward as for beams. See Pagano

To evaluate plate bending, there are several theories:

  • Membrane Theory: really thin plate like a membrane. Deformations considered large; nonlinear theory
  • Reissner Membrane Theory: thin plates with small deformation. Thus, it is a linear theory. Also considers transverse shear deformation
  • Exact Models: based on 3-D elasticity

Assumptions from Euler theory are applied to 3D plate. Thus, the 3D shape is considered as a 2D shape.

Review of Beam Theory

Assumptions:

  • Small lateral deflection
  • Cross-sections remain plane
  • Cross-sections rotate about neutral axis

The displacement of a beam is seen below, with the deformed midline being equal to the elastic curve and the angle of rotation α\alphaα. B→B∗B\to{B^*}B→B∗ and A→A∗A\to{A^*}A→A∗. w(x) is the lateral displacement at the midline z=0. u=u(x,y,z)=ui⃗+vj⃗+uk⃗u=u(x,y,z)=u\vec{i}+v\vec{j}+u\vec{k}u=u(x,y,z)=ui+vj​+uk. From the above, w(x)=uzw(x)=u_zw(x)=uz​. Thus, the x-component of displacement of point B

u=−B∗A∗sin⁡αu=-B^*A^*\sin\alphau=−B∗A∗sinα=-z\sin\alpha$. Since sin⁡α≈α\sin\alpha\approx{\alpha}sinα≈α, we have u≈−zαu\approx{-z\alpha}u≈−zα, or −ztan⁡α-z\tan\alpha−ztanα. This is approximately −zdw(x)dx-z\frac{dw(x)}{dx}−zdxdw(x)​. Since εxx=∂u∂x\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{\partial{u}}{\partial{x}}εxx​=∂x∂u​, we have:

ε=−zw′′(x)\varepsilon=-zw\prime\prime(x) ε=−zw′′(x)

  • εxx=0\varepsilon_{xx}=0εxx​=0 at z=0 (NA)

There are several assumptions on stresses:

  • the loading is on the lateral surface is distributed along the upper surface q(x)q(x)q(x). Also applied on bottom surface r(x)r(x)r(x)
  • At z=h2z=\frac{h}{2}z=2h​ (half of beam), σzz=q(x)\sigma_{zz}=q(x)σzz​=q(x), τzy=τzx=0\tau_{zy}=\tau_{zx}=0τzy​=τzx​=0
  • At z=−h2z=-\frac{h}{2}z=−2h​ (bottom half of beam), σzz=−r(x)\sigma_{zz}=-r(x)σzz​=−r(x), τzy=τzx=0\tau_{zy}=\tau_{zx}=0τzy​=τzx​=0

Since all loads in y-direction are zero, we assume all stresses in y-direction are zero throughout the bar. σyy=σyz=σxy=0\sigma_{yy}=\sigma_{yz}=\sigma_{xy}=0σyy​=σyz​=σxy​=0.

Also assumed that σzz≪σxx\sigma_{zz}\ll{\sigma_{xx}}σzz​≪σxx​. σxx\sigma_{xx}σxx​ is the stress due to bending. By taking moment about any point, Mo=σzzL+σxxhM_o=\sigma_{zz}{L}+\sigma_{xx}{h}Mo​=σzz​L+σxx​h, with h being height of cross-section. Since h≪Lh\ll{L}h≪L. we know σzz≪σxx\sigma_{zz}\ll{\sigma_{xx}}σzz​≪σxx​.

Following this, for beams, we have:

εxx=[σxx−ν(σyy+σzz)]E≈σxxE=Eεxx=−Ezw′′(x)\varepsilon_{xx}=\frac{[\sigma_{xx}-\nu (\sigma_{yy}+\sigma_{zz})]}{E}\approx\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E}=E\varepsilon_{xx}=-Ezw\prime\prime{(x)} εxx​=E[σxx​−ν(σyy​+σzz​)]​≈Eσxx​​=Eεxx​=−Ezw′′(x)

σxx\sigma_{xx}σxx​ generates a moment about y-axis. Thus, we have M(x)=∬zσxxdA=−Ew′′x∬z2dAM(x)=\iint{z\sigma_{xx}dA}=-Ew\prime\prime{x}\iint{z^2dA}M(x)=∬zσxx​dA=−Ew′′x∬z2dA, with the area being that of the z-y plane. This is equal to the moment of inertia
